upper_bound.h File Reference

Detailed Description

Computes an upper or lower bound y = f(x) on a set of (x,y) data points.

Author:
Farhan Ahammed (faha3615@mail.usyd.edu.au)

Function Documentation

void find_lower_bound ( double  func[5],
const data_point *  points,
const int  num_data_points 
)

Computes a lower bound y = f(x) on a set of (x,y) data points.

During our calculation we 'shift' the data points towards the origin and scale the points so that
(x0,y0) = (0,0) and
(x1,y1) = (1,1)
These numbers will then be incorporated into the upper bound function so that it will be shifted and scaled back towards where the data points were in the first place.

Call the returned array retval. Then
retval[0] is the order of the upper bound.
retval[1] is the distance every point is moved along the x-axis.
retval[2] is the distance every point is moved along the y-axis.
retval[3] is the (multiplicative) scale that every point is moved along the x-axis.
retval[4] is the (multiplicative) scale every point is moved along the y-axis.

The function returned will then be: y = retval[4]((x - retval[1])/retval[3])retval[0] + retval[2]

Plot some points, run this code, plot the function, then you'll understand :)

Parameters:
func An array of size 5. The upper bound function is returned in this array.
points The set of (x,y) data points to find an upper bound for.
num_data_points The size of the array points.

void find_upper_bound ( double  func[5],
const data_point *  points,
const int  num_data_points 
)

Computes an upper bound y = f(x) on a set of (x,y) data points.

During our calculation we 'shift' the data points towards the origin and scale the points so that
(x0,y0) = (0,0) and
(x1,y1) = (1,1)
These numbers will then be incorporated into the upper bound function so that it will be shifted and scaled back towards where the data points were in the first place.

Call the returned array retval. Then
retval[0] is the order of the upper bound.
retval[1] is the distance every point is moved along the x-axis.
retval[2] is the distance every point is moved along the y-axis.
retval[3] is the (multiplicative) scale that every point is moved along the x-axis.
retval[4] is the (multiplicative) scale every point is moved along the y-axis.

The function returned will then be: y = retval[4]((x - retval[1])/retval[3])retval[0] + retval[2]

Plot some points, run this code, plot the function, then you'll understand :)

Parameters:
func An array of size 5. The upper bound function is returned in this array.
points The set of (x,y) data points to find an upper bound for.
num_data_points The size of the array points.

double sum_error ( double  ub[5],
const data_point *  points,
const int  num_data_points 
)

Computes the sum of the errors of the points from the given upper bound.

The upper bound array is expected to be in the same format as the array returned in the function find_upper_bound().

The sum of the errors is computed as SUM{i=1,...,num_data_points}{ub(points[i].x) - points[i].y}.

Parameters:
ub An array of size 5 representing the upper bound function.
points The set of (x,y) data points to compute the sum of errors.
num_data_points The size of the array points.
Returns:
The sum of the errors.
